displayed_text: Family Member: Um, hum. Doctor: - for the study and on the day that he’s just starting something new- Family Member: Yeah. Right. Doctor: I would- Family Member: You want somebody here. Doctor: At least tell you that you need to be available if we need to call you. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You know? Because any new medication to your system you might have a reaction, allergic reaction, whatever. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: We just need to be prepared for that. Okay? Family Member: And that’s fine. That’s fine. I can do that. Doctor: But most of the time it doesn’t happen. But if it happens, I like to sort of be prepared for the worst.

Patient: God is gonna make sure the insurance is taken care of – Doctor: Mm, hmm. PAT - because your wasn’t for sure about the Provenge being taken care of… Patient: …and that was like what a hundred grand. Doctor: That was a hundred grand, yeah. Patient: And so and so the insurance took it right off. Doctor: Yep. Patient: We didn’t have to go to nobody. Doctor: We’re gonna make you the six million dollar man. (Laughs) Patient: Yeah, and so yeah, and so and so this is gonna pass too. Doctor: Yes. We again, we’re just being really on top of it. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So let me ask you this here because we talked about this in case it didn’t work.

Patient: I - at this point I think you all are taking pretty good care of me. So that means a lot to me and so, but I will touch base with him. Family Member: So this, I know it’s not cure. But you mentioned, you said remission a couple of times. What constitutes remission when you’re speaking of cancer? Doctor: Remission means that the cancer disappears completely. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Or partially. So the complete remission would mean that the PSA level goes to zero. Family Member: Is that something that could possibly happen in this case? Doctor: With the hormone therapy—yes. Family Member: With the hormone therapy—yes. Doctor: It happens frequently. Now it’s a bit misleading because it’s not truly zero. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s below the limit of detection, so the laboratory for example is below zero point one milligrams per ml. Family Member: Uh hum.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You mentioned before that you were taking a number of supplements and you know, we're interested in natural products and how they may help your risk of cancer or cancer progression. Doctor: So, I think that that would be a reasonable first approach to see and hear. You know, first to see if you're eligible for the study- Patient: Okay. Doctor: -and then, get the genetic testing for the study. And then if you are, join that study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright. Patient: I think that’s fair. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I think that’s reasonable. It reasonable. Doctor: Are you just agreeing with me to agree with me? Patient: No, no, no, no, no, no. Really.

Patient: Last week, yes, and my PSA jumped up tremendously. This is from last year. This is December and this is last week – up point five. Doctor: Blood count is good, tab - nothing dramatic – sporadic just below the normal range. So your kidney function goes up and down. So two months hundred at one point six, then it was repeated back down to one and then it was up at one point five. Where did you have your scan last week? Patient: In Hospital A in B___. I have the information and phone number. Doctor: So is G___ a new doctor for you or have you seen him for a while? Patient: No, that was only the second visit. And I saw him after, thoracic surgeon in Hospital B and spotted through tests, prostate cancer cells in my liver, and also on my lung Family Member: December. Patient: And that’s when he recommended I see an oncologist there. He teaches up here, too, so. He’s kind of the go-between. And he’s the one that said he’d work on the lung problem. Doctor: Just a couple more things So other than the CAT scan you haven’t had any other new scans? Patient: Not for I think about two months, three months, and I had the whole-body scan ordered by I think the thoracic surgeon V___ and that’s been the three lymph nodes on the lungs. Doctor: And that’s all you know from the last time you were here. Patient: Oh no, not since the last time I was here, no, just that one. Doctor: Okay, uh so the test results that we have is your ARV7 test. Dr. G but we had one- Patient: Uh hum.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But we have to do something different to add on to this uh treatment. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Right now to try and control the growth and growing part of the cancer. Okay? And one way to do that is there standard treatment. So there are medications, pills, hormonal pills, that you could take at home every day, and about once a month, every two or three weeks, I will need to monitor you. So you will need somewhat closer monitoring because of that. Family Member: More visits? Doctor: Yeah. The other option is uh to go on a clinical trial which will give us both these medications, and both of these medicines are IV, but you have to come even more frequently for that. Family Member: So, like every other week or something like that? Doctor: Yes. Yeah. Every two weeks we will need him here the whole day or at least half the day because we have to make sure your, uh blood counts are okay, everything is okay, and then we give you the IV medicine, and, you know, either way- Patient: Radiation? Doctor: Yes, both the radiation, the radiation is once a month, but the IV immune therapy is once every two weeks. Okay? Family Member: So the thing is, Dr. V___, - Doctor: Um, hum. Family Member: - kind of sounds like a plan, and we trust you explicitly. This is my only concern. Because J___’s safety is not a concern.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh and then they pretty much send you home. Um and they, they’ve been treating about every two months, so. Patient: So then you go back again? Doctor: Potentially, yeah. Patient: Potentially? Doctor: I know they’ve done uh I want to say up to four treatments I’ve seen at the most for every two months or so. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: They, they uh, I don’t think they’ve worked out totally the scheme of what’s the best way to do it, every two months at most it’s been. Each center does it slightly different. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh but that’s, that’s about what they do. Uh I’m not really sure because they haven’t seen profound bone marrow effects. One of the problems with radioactive things is you can get- Patient: Sure. Um hum. Doctor: Injury to the bone marrow. My experience with them is that particularly with patients who’ve had, not had a lot of chemotherapy, so not a lot of things to injure the bone marrow, they don’t seem to really have a problem with bone marrow toxicity from this study.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And on a clinical trial, we don’t know if more is better, but that third drug, if you were to get it, starts to kill cancer cells. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: If you don’t get it- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - you still have two things that we know kill cancer cells that make people live longer. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so do we just sort of like stay low or if you get better, if the prostate shrinks and we are able to get the catheter out, then we did the right thing. Or if time goes on and you still have trouble getting that catheter out, uh would radiation help? Is it because the drugs aren’t doing what they need to do to shrink it to allow you to have a reasonable channel to get the pee out? Um and that’s sort of – before when we had chemo and before we had these super hormones, some of us would send you to radiation. And then now we don’t know because you can’t get the radiation and the chemo and the hormone all at the same time. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Because that’s just way too much. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Now, is he going to have a body scan at one point to see what’s happening with the cancer cells? Uh she should have that body scan uh that Dr. ____ said that it’s . Now is it down the road? Is it something that you plan to do or does it matter? Or how would you know that the cancer is shrinking? Patient: That the cancer is shrinking.

Patient: Okay.That’s yours Okay and this is Doctor: That is a problem as is the … ORIOLE trial. Patient: Okay. And, this is for me? Doctor: That is your copy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: As is this diagram Patient: Okay. Doctor: Do you have any other questions that arise immediately that you want to discuss? Patient: Uh, and you may not be able to are you gonna be able to check when Doctor: Yeah so that’s a good question. So um there’s an easy answer to that and there’s a more easy answer to that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The easy answer is if you ever develop symptoms from your cancer. For example, if the cancer has spread to your bone or if the cancer in the lymph node causing a blood obstruction. stop the

Patient: Yeah. I got to say this only happened probably all that driving. Doctor: Yeah. If that’s no better, we need to know. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Oh hi, Come on in. Healthcare Professional: Hello. Patient: How are you doing? Doctor: We chatted about all sorts of things. Healthcare Professional: What did you give him because I have him coming back for the spinal? Doctor: He’ll come back after he gets scanned which will probably be like in a week or two. Healthcare Professional: Okay, so then we will, because he’s due to come back on the 18th and he’ll have research labs then, so that will be a different one. Doctor: I think so. We’ll try to make sure that we have a plan. Healthcare Professional: Okay Doctor: He can’t get rid of us now. Sit tight.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because I need to check, if that, that we were to move you to, let’s say your AR-V7 was positive - Patient: Right. Doctor: They may want you to stay on the Enzalutamide. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Or we could stop the TGF-A drug. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, then, you could move into that study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are AR-V7 negative and, uh, phase one study is of more interest to you, we can say, “Okay, you’re gonna stop as of this date the, the current study.” Patient: Right-- the drugs Doctor: And then we could reserve the slot for the new trial.

Family Member: Hormone therapy does? Doctor: Yeah, because it castrates you. It puts you into menopause. And we can talk some more about that. The um uh - another approach, so if we do that; let’s just focus on that, knowing that the cancer is down here in the pelvis, if you look at all the guys that get treated with radiation plus hormones and you look five years from now- Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: everybody’s alive, okay. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Half the guys have their cancer come back, meaning they weren’t cured by the surgery, radiation and hormones. Half of the guys are cured by the hormones and radiation. You know it sort of mops up what’s left. Okay, so at minimum the standard of care is for you to do radiation plus hormones. I can tell you why they have the hormones. If they do the radiation alone, only thirty percent of the guys are cured five years from now. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The good news is just so you hear it, is half the guys are cured at five years and then if you look ten years down – Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the line, nine out of ten guys are still alive if you go through the hormones and surgery, hormones and radiation, okay. Patient: Sure, uh hum. Doctor: You may be fighting prostate cancer, but you’re alive.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::strongly agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::strongly agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.strongly agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::strongly agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

Please feel free to leave any comments a.text_box: The radio buttons were very small and hard to activate

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’re just you know, we’re having our usual conversation that we have. What’s new? What’s the deal with going to Alabama and going straight, no breaks? Patient: I took breaks, but I just didn’t take enough. Doctor: Is your leg swollen? Can I take a look? Patient: Yeah. Might have to pull this down. Doctor: Why don’t you come on up here and see what’s going on. Patient: It’s up in here where it’s been. Doctor: Really? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Well, we can’t, you know. That part’s okay. Let me see this other skinny leg. Patient: Yeah, you’re right they’re skinny. Doctor: There’s no change there so that’s good but you think up here is swollen? Patient: Well, no, I don’t think it’s swollen. It’s just like a…

Family Member: Well, it’s working then. Doctor: Any issues with your mood or depression? Why do you take the Wellbutrin? Patient: Well, the Wellbutrin was so I wouldn’t smoke much. Doctor: So, it’s not for your mood or depression? Patient: No. Doctor: And any issues with anxiety? Patient: No. Doctor: Acid reflux? Patient: No. Doctor: Do you still have your appendix? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Still have your gallbladder? Patient: Yes.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Let me see. Yeah Patient: Yeah… Doctor: it looks pretty good. Pretty smooth. Patient: Yeah and it – this is not from my shaving. I ran into the garage door because I I Doctor: Ohh. Patient: didn’t allow it to get high enough. I bent my head - Doctor: Because you were in a rush. Patient: I was in a rush to get out. (Laughs) Doctor: Stop that! Alright sit tight here. Let me go get her. Patient: Okay. Doctor: She just wants to wave and kick you out. Patient: Okay. Thank you very much.
